ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about atmospheric chemistry, meteorology, air pollution, and their relation to public health and everyday life.

I learned all about air pollution  the atmosphere and how the planetary boundary layer affects concentrations of pollutants, how organic and inorganic aerosols are formed and emitted, the health effects of pollutants, and how radiative forcing from pollutants can generate either a warming or cooling effect.
Problem solving, critical thinking, assessing air quality studies and issues, atmospheric chemistry.

I learned about air pollution dynamics, causes, and management, past and present, and developed strategies to understand and address air quality issues. I also learned more about computational methods for data analysis through the final project.

Great introductory overview of air pollution issues, air chemistry with various pollutants, policy regimes adopted to mitigate air pollution, and a general introduction to the thought approach to managing issues of pollution. Very well-taught course that emphasized student learning and put us through practical exercises in class and for homework assignments, rather than pointless pset problems that seem tangentially related to the course material. Well organized and taught. Highly recommend.

You develop problem solving skills to approach an air pollution issue. This was done by gaining knowledge of pollutants and their characteristics, emission sources, meteorology, atmospheric chemistry, etc.
Overall great course to learn about air pollution problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was honestly my favorite class that I have ever taken. The lectures were structured well, the project was really fun, and while the homework was difficult, it was very applicable to what we were learning in class.

Strengths: This class was probably my favorite class this semester! Professor Gentner is incredibly caring and commutative; the class content is taught in a way that incorporates group activities and active learning methods, and Professor Gentner is constantly looking for ways to improve / adapt his teaching style so that it's accessible to everyone; the content of the course itself was extremely interesting and relevant while not being overly difficult workload wise.
Weaknesses: Absolutely NONE! Amazing class, amazing professor, I have no complaints!

I liked how the course was structured around building up a framework for how to analyze air quality problems, and I thought that I had a pretty good understanding of the material by the end. I also liked the way the class was split between lecture and group activities to help us stay engaged. I did feel like some of the group activities were not giving us enough direction (the discussion questions were sometimes pretty vague) so it was a bit confusing at times to know what we were supposed to discuss and our group discussions sometimes reached dead ends.
Strengths: strong focus on student learning, interactive environment, Professor Gentner's lively energy, support from TA and TFs, practical exercises, in-depth exposure for undergrads
In class activities were engaging and helped solidify concepts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you are even remotely interested in environmental engineering, air quality, or public health, I definitely recommend this course.

YES! Take this class! Professor Gentner is great and this class has made me want to take his grad level class. Also, this class has made me potentially want to study the atmospheric side of climate science in my future education.
Yes, it was very helpful for the environmental engineering map.
Yes, it's a really interesting course and (as far as engineering courses go) not too hard.

Yes, 100%. Professor Gentner is fantastic and the material is taught in an interesting way that actually stimulates you to think about air pollution issues critically, rather than merely memorizing facts and regurgitating them on assignments or exams. I really liked the course and I have found myself thinking about the material of the course quite often.
